STATE OF MICHIGAN
GRETCHEN WHITMER DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES ROBERT GORDON
GOVERNOR LANSING DIRECTOR
January 24, 2019
Tracey Silas
Wayne County DHS – South Central
1801 East Canfield
Detroit, MI 48207
RE: License #: CP820201496
Wayne County DHHS – South Central
1801 East Canfield
Detroit, MI 48207
Dear Ms. Silas:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
01/09/2019. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Christopher Barr, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-2282
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
LicenseLicense #: CP820201496
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Tracey Silas, Administrator
Herman McCall, Designee
Name of Facility: Wayne County DHHS – South Central
Facility Address: 1801 East Canfield
Detroit, MI 48207
Facility Telephone #: (313) 578-5102
Original Issuance Date: 09/03/1993
Service Types: SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site Inspection(s): 12/11, 12/14, 1218, and 12/20/2018
Total No. Of Records No. of Records
Reviewed

2

METHODS OF INSPECTION – B. Analyst

3

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
Two out of eight applicable foster care records reviewed did not contain updated
physical exams. In one case record the last physical examination occurred on
04/04/2017, whereas the current examination occurred on 07/11/2018, one month
late. The other case record had an examination dated 09/17/2017 and did not have
an updated examination on file.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(d) Current immunizations for each child as required by
section 5111 of 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.5111. All of the
following apply:
(i) A statement from a parent or licensed medical authority
which indicates that immunizations are current or
contraindicated is sufficient documentation of immunizations.
Two out of eight foster care records reviewed were deficient with updated
immunizations. In one case DTP/DTAP/DT/TD/TDAP was overdue on 04/07/2018,
and Hep A and Polio being overdue on 09/14/2018. In the second case no
immunizations were noted as occurring within MiSACWIS. The physical
examination dated 06/29/2018 indicates the clinic requesting immunization records
from out of state, as well a request for the agency to obtain immunization records
from the parents or out of state clinic with a return of one to two weeks.
Repeat Citation from 02/27/2018 Interim Inspection Report
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
4

(ii) A dental reexamination shall be obtained at least every
18 months, unless a greater frequency is indicated.
One out of eight applicable case records reviewed contained an overdue dental
examination. The previous dental examination occurred on 07/26/2016, whereas
the current dental examination occurred on 06/14/2018, five months late.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a) Child's name – (j) Authorization to provide routine and
emergency medical care.
Four out of eight applicable case records reviewed contained deficient signatures,
late, incomplete, and deficient DHHS 3307 forms. One form was uploaded but not
signed by the relative. In the second case the child was placed on 05/08/2018,
whereas the form was not signed by the foster parent until 05/11/2018. It is noted
that the ongoing case manager completed the form rather than the placing CPS
worker. The third case was missing some information on the form, whereas the forth
case did not contain the form.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
One out of eight applicable case records reviewed contained a late initial service
plan by seven days.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Two out of eight applicable case records reviewed contained one late updated
service plan each by one and four days.
Repeat Citation from 02/27/2018 Interim Inspection Report
5

2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.16.1 - Relative Foster Parents (Commitment 52).
Page 23
(a) When placing a child with a relative who has not been
previously licensed as a foster parent, DHHS shall:
(1) prior to placement, visit the relative’s home to determine that
it is safe.
One out of eight applicable foster care record reviewed did not contain
documentation that the relative’s home was visited to determine that it was safe prior
to the child’s placement. The child was placed on 06/08/2018, whereas the DHHS
588 form indicates a home visit as occurring on 06/11/2018.
Repeat Citation from 02/27/2018 Interim Inspection Report
ISEP 6.33(c) Assessments and Service Plans, Content (Commitment 69).
Page 28
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of
age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not
available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall
include an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and
shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
Three out of eight case records reviewed did not contain birth parent signatures
on service plans. One case record was deficient four service plan signatures,
whereas two case records were deficient by one each.
Repeat Citation from 02/27/2018 Interim Inspection Report
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
6

DHHS Policy Placement with Relatives
FOM 722-03B
Page 4
When children are placed in out-of-home care, preference must
be given to placement with a relative. Safety assessments,
safety planning (when appropriate), and background checks.
One out of eight applicable foster care record reviewed did not contain
documentation that the relative’s home was visited to determine that it was safe prior
to the child’s placement. The child was placed on 06/08/2018, whereas the DHHS
588 form indicates a background check as occurring on 06/11/2018.
DHHS Policy Relative Placement Home Study
FOM 722-03B
Page 13-14
The DHS-3130A, Relative Placement Home Study, must be
completed within the timeframes described below:
• For initial/emergency placements, within 30 calendar days of
the child’s placement in the relative home.
One out of eight applicable foster care record reviewed did not contain 3130A within
30 calendar days of placement. The child was placed on 10/16/2018, whereas the
3130A was completed on 12/12/2018.
Repeat Citation from 02/27/2018 Interim Inspection Report
DHHS Policy Medical Passports
FOM 801 Page
11-13
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Legal parents, if the child is a temporary court ward.
• The child’s foster care provider.
• All medical and mental health professionals.
7

Seven out of eight foster care records reviewed were deficient with quarterly
updates, whereas two did not contain birth parent signatures.
An additional three case records identified during the analyst visits were also
deficient with relative signatures.
Repeat Citation from 02/27/2018 Interim Inspection Report
DHHS Policy Supervisory Approval – USP
FOM 722-09
Page 27
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
• Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report date.
One out of eight case records reviewed contained one late supervisor signature of
an USP by three days.
Repeat Citation from 02/27/2018 Interim Inspection Report
DHHS Policy Required Participation in Development - Foster Parent /
FOM 722-08C Caregiver
Page 2
The foster parent/caregiver signature is required and indicates
that the foster parent/caregiver acknowledges and agrees to the
activities required to meet the needs of the child in their care.
Four out of eight case records reviewed contained deficient foster parent signatures
on service plans. One case was missing signatures for one report period, whereas
two cases were missing two report periods, and one case record indicated that the
service plan was sent to the foster parent.
Repeat Citation from 02/27/2018 Interim Inspection Report
DHHS Policy Sibling Visitation and Ongoing Interaction
FOM 722-06I
Page 11-12
Siblings in foster care, who are not placed together, must have
at least one visit per calendar month that is in addition to
parenting time.
8

Five out of eight applicable case records reviewed did not contain documentation of
monthly sibling visits occurring. The first case record did not contain monthly visits
for three consecutive report periods. The second case record missed two monthly
visits in one report period. The third case record missed a visit within the first month
of placement. The forth case record missed one monthly visit in one report period.
And the fifth case record missed a visit within the first month of placement and the
first report period.
Repeat Citation from 02/27/2018 Interim Inspection Report
DHHS Policy Caseworker Contact with Child in Out-of-Home Placement
FOM 722-6H
Page 5
First Two Months after Initial Placement or a Placement Move.
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts
per month with the child for the first two months following an
initial placement or a placement move.
One out of eight applicable case records reviewed did not contain two contacts with
the child within the first month of placement.
DHHS Policy Unannounced Home Visit – Caseworker Contact with
FOM 722-6H – Caregivers
Page 7
The caseworker must make an unannounced visit to the home
every quarter. The unannounced visit must be documented in
MiSACWIS.
Five out of eight applicable case records reviewed did not document unannounced
visits as occurring. Three case records were deficient unannounced visits for two
report periods, whereas two case records were deficient unannounced visits for one
report period each.
An additional three case records identified during the analyst visits were also
deficient with unannounced visits.
Repeat Citation from 02/27/2018 Interim Inspection Report
DHHS Policy Caseworker Contact with Parent(s) / Guardian(s)
FOM 722-06H
Page 10
First two months - The caseworker must have at least two face-
to-face contacts with each parent/guardian, at least one of
which must occur in the parent’s residence.
9

The caseworker must have face-to-face contact with each
parent/guardian at least once each calendar month, with at least
one contact in each quarter occurring in the parent’s place of
residence.
Five out of eight applicable case records reviews did not contain two face to face
contacts with birth parents within the first two months of placement or quarterly
home visits. The first case record did not contain contacts or the first two months of
placement, nor throughout the reporting periods. The second case did not contain
contacts when the birth father was ordered into care. The third did not contain home
visits for two report periods. The forth did not contain face to face contacts with birth
parents within the first two months of placement or quarterly home visits. The fifth
did not contain face to face contact with birth parents within the first two months of
placement or for the first quarter.
Repeat Citation from 02/27/2018 Interim Inspection Report
DHHS Policy Family Team Meeting
722-06B page1-7
-Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 14 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
-Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
-Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
-Permanency Goal Review at Six Months in Care
-Within 30 calendar days from the date the child has been in
care for six months.
-Permanency Goal Change. Within 30 calendar days before the
date of the goal change.
Placement Preservation/Disruption. At least three business
days prior to a planned change of placement or no later than
three business days after an unplanned placement change.
10

Six out of eight applicable case records reviewed did not have documentation of
an FTM occurring. Three case records did not contain documentation of an FTM
occurring within the first month of placement. Four case records did not contain
documentation of one quarterly FTM’s occurring.
One additional case record identified during the analyst visit was also deficient
with a timely FTM.
Repeat Citation from 02/27/2018 Interim Inspection Report
Communication Treatment Plan Signature Timeframes and
Issuance 17-099 Documentation Requirements
All treatment plans with a report date of August 1, 2017, or later
must have signatures from all appropriate case members within
30 days of the report date.
One out of eight applicable case records reviewed contained foster parent
signatures beyond 30 days.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) For a child under 2 years of age, a physical examination shall
have been completed within 3 months before being placed in
foster care or a new physical examination shall be completed
within 30 calendar days after being placed in foster care.
One out of eight applicable case records reviewed contained Care Connect 360
verification within MiSACWIS. The physical examination was noted in file though not
uploaded into MiSACWIS. All medical information must be uploaded into
MiSACWIS.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
11

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Th agency submitted corrective action plans since the last interim inspection dated
02/27/2018.
The Interim Inspection report dated 02/27/2018 resulted in a corrective action plan
that successfully addressed all the following as no repeat citations are noted:
Updated picture, face to face with child within 5 days of placement, progress note
completion, birth parent signatures on treatment plans, and semi-annual transition
meetings occurring. Repeat citations include: Current immunizations, late USP’s,
30-day relative assessments, quarterly and signed medical passports, supervisor
approval of treatment plans within 14-days, foster parent signature on treatment
plans, unannounced home visits, birth parent monthly contacts and quarterly home
visits, and completion of family team meetings.
Special investigation report #2018C0219047, initiated on 05/03/2018, cited the
agency for failing to enroll a YAVC, monitor the case, and appropriately discharge
the case. The corrective action appears to have been successful as no repeat
citations are noted.
The 01/05/2019 analyst report was reviewed and follow up to safety issues and
concerns are as follows:
Safety and Concern Alert #1:
Urgent: A 13-month-old baby is sleeping in a play pen in the living room.
Resolution: The agency had a crib delivered to the relative on
12/28/2018. Another crib was secured and set up on 01/07/2019
due to the original crib missing pieces. The agency reports an
approved pack-n-play and considered safe sleep was used prior to
the crib being secured.
Critical: The two foster children share the same bed.
Resolution: The agency had two twin beds and mattresses
delivered to the relative on 12/28/2018. The agency reports the
sisters who were previously sharing a queen size bed did not have
any noted concerns or issues that would have prevented them from
sharing the bed.
Concern: Relative reported foster care worker hasn't made any unannounced
home visits.
12

Resolution: Case record review indicates no unannounced visits
occurring. An unannounced visit occurred on 01/14/2019. The
agency is cited as noncompliant.
Concern: Relative reported not receiving a medical passport for foster
children in care
Resolution: Case record review indicates medical passports not
being given to the relative at time of placement for three children,
whereas the forth child’s record had one signed. The agency
consequently had the relative sign medical passports for all the
children on 12/27/2018. The agency is cited as noncompliant.
Concern: Relative reported not participating in at least one family team
meeting
Resolution: Case record review indicates the relative attending and
signing the family team meeting form on 10/08/2018.
Concern: There are not enough sufficient beds in the household.
Resolution: Two twin beds and a crib were delivered to the relative
home on 12/28/2018.
Concern: Relative doesn't feel supported by the agency
Resolution: Case record review indicates the case manager
providing the relative with multiple community resources, which she
expressed dissatisfaction with noting they were still not enough
resources. The relative was also referred for licensure at time of
placement, which she was noncompliant. The agency indicates the
relative’s statement is subjective as the case manager provided her
with support beyond the treatment plan referrals and visits.
Concern: The 15-year-old foster child reported not participating in any
transitional meetings and not being familiar with MYOI.
Resolution: Case record review indicates a pre-meeting discussion
with the parents and caregivers at court on 11/29/2018 which
included discussion about MYOI and transitional planning. An FTM
was held on 01/03/2019 to include the youth and relative in which
MYOI and transitional planning was addressed. The agency is
cited as noncompliant for timely FTM completion.
Safety and Concern Alert #2:
13

Urgent: Relative reported never receiving medical authorization cards for
both foster children in care.
Resolution: Case record review indicates the emergency services
medical card being given to relative at time of placement. Case
manager discussed with relative how she was obtaining current
medical care for the children and noted the green medical cards
were sent to her via mail.
Critical: The two foster children share the same bed.
Resolution: Case record review indicates the two children sharing
a bed are sisters who have no known behaviors or concerns and
that temporarily sharing a bed would not be a risk. A SER referral
for bunk beds was completed in 10/2018 and again in 11/2018 after
no response. An escalated request for processing was then
submitted in 12/2018, which was initially denied and then approved
after administrative intervention. The bunk beds are expected to
arrive for delivery on 01/10/2019.
Critical: The basement area is used as recreational space without an
egress window.
Resolution: Case records review indicates the case manager
speaking with the relative on 12/28/2018, as well as during previous
home visits, informing her that the basement is not to be used as a
recreational space. The relative verbally agreed not to use the
basement and signed a basement usage agreement on
01/09/2019.
Concern: Relative reported foster care worker hasn't made any unannounced
home visits.
Resolution: Case record review indicates the last unannounced
home visit occurring on 03/15/2018. The most recent unannounced
visit occurred on 01/10/2019. The agency is cited as noncompliant.
Concern: Relative reported not receiving medical passports for foster children
in care.
Resolution: Case record review indicates the relative last signing a
medical passport on 06/26/2017. A updated medical passport
dated 01/24/2019 will be given to the relative. The agency is cited
as noncompliant.
14

Critical: There is not enough sufficient beds in the household.
Resolution: A SER referral for bunk beds was completed in
10/2018 and again in 11/2018 after no response. An escalated
request for processing was then submitted in 12/2018, which was
initially denied and then approved after administrative intervention.
The bunk beds are expected to arrive for delivery on 01/10/2019.
Safety and Concern Alert #3:
Concern: Relative reported not receiving the medical passports for children in
care.
Resolution: Case record review indicates relative caregiver signing
the medical passport on 12/07/2018.
Concern: Relative reported not participating in at least one family team
meeting.
Resolution: Case record review indicates relative caregiver
participating in family team meetings on 10/30/2018 and
01/03/2019 as signed forms are in file.
Concern: Relative reported there is no parenting time taking place between
children and their mother.
Resolution: Case record review indicates birth parent visitation is
allowed by the designee and that the relative has agreed to
supervise the visits. Birth mother has not participated in visitation.
The case manager has attempted to schedule visitations and has
offered to change the schedule, location, dates and times, as well
as offering her bus tickets. Birth mother indicates she will visit at
the relatives and does not need assistance.
Concern: 14-year-old foster child reported she was not involved in the
development of her service plan, participated in no transitional
meetings and is not familiar with MYOI.
Resolution: Case record review indicates youth receiving
psychiatric services since prior to entering care. The case manager
maintains regular contact with the youth to assess adjustment,
needs, and services. The youth’s stability is required prior to
scheduling a transitional FTM and introduction of MYOI as noted in
the 01/03/2019 FTM.
Concern: Birth parent reported not signing, providing input or being provided
15

with a service plan.
Resolution: Case record review indicates birth mother signing the
initial service plan and parent agency treatment plan on
11/19/2018, as well as attending a family team meeting on
01/03/2019.
Safety and Concern Alert #4:
Concern: Relative reported not receiving the medical passport for child in
care.
Resolution: Case record review indicates a medical passport was
not signed by the relative at time of placement. The case manager
will present and obtain signatures during the next home visit on
01/30/2019. The agency is cited as non-compliant.
Concern: Relative reported foster care worker not making any unannounced
home visits.
Resolution: Case record review indicates unannounced home
visits as not occurring. It is noted that the relative reside an hour
and a half away and that the relative has a flexible work. An
unannounced visit is scheduled for 01/30/2019. The agency is
cited as noncompliant.
Safety and Concern Alert #5:
Concern: Relative reported that the foster care worker hasn't made any
unannounced home visits.
Resolution: Case record review indicates unannounced visits
occurring on 06/29/2018, 07/18/2018, 09/27/2018, 10/23/2018, and
12/13/2018.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
16

01/24/2019
________________________________________
Christopher Barr Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
January 24, 2019
________________________________________
Linda D. Tansil Date
Area Manager
17

metadata.agency_name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
